millsfield:images_texts:
Balfo Crosses the South Atlantic
December 17, 1930 • Rome (near Orbetello), Italy
100F
GÉNÉRAL ITALO BALBO
REPUBLIQUE DU TCHAD
ROMA
FIL
17.12. 83

International Tributes to the History of Flight
Balfo Crosses the South Atlantic
Italo Balbo, Italy's Minister of Aviation, organized
one of aviation's most well-known flights in 1930.
Unlike many previous aviation feats, this was a group
rather than a solo effort. Balbo orchestrated the for-
mation flight of 14 Savoia-Marchetti S-55A flying boats
across the South Atlantic. This well-planned event
drew attention to Italy as a major force in the world
of aviation. The flight, which began on December 17,
1930, took these Italian aircraft and their pilots from
Orbetello (north of Rome) to Spain, Morocco, Por-
tuguese Guinea, and Brazil. On January 16, 1931, the
planes arrived in Rio de Janiero, their final destination.
While only 11 of the 14 aircraft actually made the
entire flight, the Savoia-Marchetti proved to be a
viable commercial aircraft and Italy showed the world
its commitment to the development of international
flight routes.
The full-color cachet shows the array of colors used
to paint the hulls of the planes in this flying armada.
The formation mirrored Italy's flag by combining red,
green, and white painted hulls.
Mint stamp: The mint stamp on this Cover was issued
by the Republic of Chad in 1978. It portrays the twin-
hulled seaplane used by Balbo for this historic South
Atlantic crossing.
Postmark: This Cover was postmarked in Rome, near
Orbetello, Italy, on December 17, 1983, marking the
anniversary of the beginning of this historic flight.
© Postal Commemorative Society
Printed in U.S.A.
2019.056.031
properties.sfomuseum:description: Airmail flight cover, part of International Tributes to the History of Flight series by the Postal Commemorative Society; white envelope with full color illustration cachet and inset stamp commemorating Balbo crossing the South Atlantic on December 17, 1930, Rome, Italy, by Italo Balbo with Savoia-Marchetti S-55A flying boat; commemorative cancellation stamp dated December 17, 1983 in Rome; includes information on reverse.
